The Marge Mareck Support
Committee wants to bring to
your attention the circumstances
surrounding Marge Mareck's
dismissal from the Johns Hopkins University's Eisenhower

ask that a fair grievance procedure be established. There will
be a demonstration on Monday,
February 23, at 2:30 p.m., at
Shriver Hall.

To the Editor:
In response to the letter of
MS. Laura Rosenthal which appeared in last week's N-L, I
would like to make the following statements.
The "D.U.'s Back" poster
which you found "sexist and
offensive " displayed the rear
view of a woman whose buttocks were properly draped.

poster artistically expressed the

To the Editor:
I am writing in response to a
letter in your Feb. 6, 1980 issue
that claims "that WJHU is very
quickly being taken over by
outsiders" and implies that Hopkins does not have a lot to say
into who runs the station." The
author of that letter has not
only mangled the English language, but has mangled the facts as
well. Initially, only the students
and alumni of The Johns Hopkins University were allowed to
participate in the activities at
WJHU because WJHU was an
organization of the SAC. But
when WJHU received its FM
license, a decision was made by
the WJHU Managing Board
(composed entirely of Hopkins
students) in conjunction with
the Hopkins administration, to
make WJHU a Uiliversity activity
managed and operated by students, rather than a "student
activity."
Members of the
community surrounding the Uni-

versity had offered their services
to WJHU,and had begun helping
out around the station on an
informal basis because they still
could not officially become
members. As their contributions
became greater and the WJHU
staff and management became
more aware of the value of their
work, it was decided to consider
and vote upon the issue of
community members becoming
official members of the WJHU
staff. The matter was discussed
and voted upon at a General
Staff meeting, and the majority
of the staff members in attendance voted in favor of allowing
community members full voting
representation. However, the
decision did not rest solely with
the student staff at the station.
Dr. Muller's approval was required and susbsequently given.
That decision was reached
because community members
have become a vital part of
WJHU's operation and have
shown a sense of dedication and
involvement on a year-round
basis that Hopkins students have
sometimes been hard put to
match. This is understandable
considering the course workload
that students must bear, and the
vacation periods that are needed
to recover from it. But it creates
a continual problem because
WJHU does indeed have to abide
by the .commitments it has
made, first to Hopkins President
Steven Muller acting on the part
of the Trustees, and more
recently to the Federal Governregulation
ment (due
to
changes), to stay on the air 365
days a year.
Every year at student vacation times, the Program Director
and music directors have had to
beg and plead with student staff
members to try and stay during
at least part of the vacation to
keep the station on the air the
required eighteen hours a day.
And each year, it has been a
skeleton staff of 20 or less
members that have managed to
come in and help out, at least 60
percent of whom were community members (by actual count).

And the backbone of that
skeleton staff has been 75 to
100 percent community members, also by actual count. After
all, would you be willing to give
up a trip home to New York, or
Boston or California, etc.just to
put your show on the air? And
that brings up another important
point. According to the admissions office, more than 75% of
the undergraduate students at
Hopkins are out-of-state students. Add to that number,
those students from outside of
Baltimore, and you have relatively few students familiar with the
history, politics, or "beat" of
this city. Yet it is the people of
the City of Baltimore that
WJHU is obligated to serve. The
anonymous letter writer (ALW)
states that "the purpose of the
station is to give students an
opportunity for having fun while
learning some journalism skills.
I submit that the first purpose of
any licensed radio station is to
produce quality programming
for the entire community (for
which the students at Johns
Hopkins are a measurable part),
and that other considerations_Are
secondary, although they may
still be of great importance. The
two people that ALW mentions
as seemingly dangerous are two
of the people that have been
around during vacations when
ALW was probably basking in
the sun somewhere. And since
one must still be a Hopkins
student or alum to be a Managing Board member (until the
administration decides otherwise), it should be noted that
the Program Director is a student here.
And to top off the stupidity of
the statements in ALW's ignominious letter, the News Director
who is slanderously refered to as
"a product of the Baltimore
Hitler movement" is as Jewish
as a bagel from a New York deli.
In conclusion, I would also
like to direct a comment to the
Trustees in regard to backing
the proposed 13,720 watt station. (You blew it again, ALW.
It's not 15,000 watts.) The

FCC has recently taken action
against one or more college
stations to fight against just
what ALW states should be the
purpose of WJHU's existance.
The students operating the stations were not trying to serve
the greater community. They
were operating the stations "for
fun". Maybe that's why the
Corporation for Public Broadcasting has taken to refering to
some college stations as "electronic sandboxes". I hope no
one allows that to happen here.
Oh, and a hearty thanks to the
community members at WJHU
for a job well done!
Jud French

The importance of the NASA decision to locate
the Space Telescope Science Institute at Homewood is
difficult to judge. It will affect everything from office
space in Rowland Hall to man's view of the Universe.
Exactly what discoveries will be made is uncertain,
though certain ideas exist as to the kinds of things
man will be looking for.
The effect all this will have on Hopkins is also
difficult to ascertain, but some preliminary information
is circulating. Completion of the Institute is at least two
years away (in fact, construction won't start until this
summer). But Institute staff will begin their infiltration
this March. An initial staff of five is expected in early
March. They will be temporarily housed in Rowland
Hall until the Institute building is completed in 1983 or
1984. By May or June, 15 to 20 Institute staff members
will be cramming the halls of Rowland. After that, the
staff won't increase much until the Institute building is
completed.
The Space Telescope is already under construction. It will be placed in orbit about 375 miles above
the earth by the Space Shuttle in late 1984 or early
1985. The telescope will have a useful life of about 15
years. Adjunct Professor William Fastie of the Physics
department seemed to flinch slightly at the suggestion
that the Space Telescope, like Skylab, might drop out of
orbit and be destroyed. This is no longer a problem, he
asserts, because calculations of the earth's gravitational
pull are now more accurate. In addition, with the Space
Shuttle in operation, when and if the Space Telescope
were pulled too close to the earth, the shuttle could
simply go put it back where it belongs. (Fastie also
pointed out that if the government had adequately
funded the Space Shuttle project it would have probably
been operational in time to save the Skylab.) In addition to being able to adjust the Space Telescope's orbit,
the Space Shuttle will enable NASA to repair the telescope in space, as well as replace obsolete equipment
with more sophisticated equipment when and if desired.
The Institute will be constructed on the Homewood west campus, west of San Martin drive. The site is
north of the Athletic Center. Thouse definite plans have
not been made, the building will cover approximately
70,000 square feet, including parking. The present
design also had provisions for two 20,000-square-foot
extensions if the Institute needs to expand. The building will house a full time staff of about 140, 25 to 40 of
whom will be professional astronomers. In addition to
the full time staff, an estimated 200 astronomers are
expected to visit and use the facilities annually.
There will be no antennae at the Institute. All
communications between the Institute and the Space
Telescope will be handled through Goddard Space Flight
Center in Greenbelt, Md. The information from the
telescope will be relayed by one of two satellites to
Goddard, and then by cable from Goddard to the
Institute. Directional information for aiming the telescope will be formulated at the Institute and relayed

great technical achievement. The major advantage of
placing a telescope in orbit is that it will not have a
blanket of atmosphere fuzzing its view of the sky. The
earth's atmosphere blots out extremely faint objects and
blurs those which we can observe, so most distant
objects appear as almost featureless patches of light.
Even though the space telescope is smaller than the
largest ground-based telescope, it will be the most
optically precise instrument ever created, with a resolution (ability to show fine detail) 105 times greater than
any ground instrument. Its accuracy in pinpointing a
section of sky will go down to one 4000th of a second
of arc. (There are 180 degrees of arc from horizon to
horizon, 60 minutes per degree, and 60 seconds per
minute.) Therefore, the space telescope will be accurate to 1/2592000000 of the sky, a precision far surpassing any device on earth. Mounted within the casing will
be the optical portions of the telescope and a spectrograph, whose components are being tested here at
Hopkins.
As a tool for astronomy and astrophysics, the
space telescope will be incomparable. One of the great
mysteries of astrophysic is the nature and origin of quasars.
Quasars (short for quasi-stellar objects) were first discovered with radio telescopes and have remained an
enigma to science ever since. Quasars are distant objects
which put out enormous amounts of energy--too much,
it seems, to have been produced by a normal galaxy.
Because quasars are extremely distant objects, our only
optical pictures of them are fuzzy at best. Several
conjectures have been made on what the quasars are, but
all of these guesses really depend upon getting a clearer
look at a quasar. Are quasars galaxies with enormous
black holes in their nuclei? Do they represent an early
stage in galactic evolution? (Since light travels at a
finite constant velocity and the quasars are uniformly
distant, astronomers infer that quasars are relatively old
objects.) Some fuzzy patches have been observed

around quasars, thus leading to-the conjecture that they
could be galaxies, but the fuzzy regions could also be gas
between us and the quasar. If it is indeed gas, then there
is more intergalactic matter than expected; if they are
galaxies, then why haven't we observed any closer
quasars? The fuzzy regions around the quasars are
moving away from us at a slower speed than the quasars
themselves, which could imply that the fuzzy patches
are enormous amounts of gas being expelled from the
quasar. (Even though both the quasar and the gas are
moving away from us, the slower-receding gas indicates
that it is moving away relative to the quasar.) Everything concerning the quasars literally remains to be seen.
Another subject of scrutiny for the space telescope which may in turn aid our understanding of
quasars are the Seyfert galaxies. Both the optical spectra
of the Seyfert galaxies and the optical/ultraviolet spectra
of the quasars indicate large, turbulent cauldrons of gas
heated by powerful ultraviolet sources, an indicator of a
possible black hole at the Seyfert's nucleus. Indeed,
Seyfert galaxies may be mini-quasars, but a clearer
picture of a Seyfert galaxy may dispell this theory.
Some galaxies are powerful radio sources, and it may be
discovered that they are the real astrophysical relatives
of the quasars.
Black holes are a subject of constant interest for
astrophysicists, and naturally the space telescope will be
trained on possible black holes in our neighborhood of
the galaxy. Several nearby stars (such as the famous
Cygnus X-1) are binary stars with invisible, massive
companions which are strong X-ray sources. Unseen
companion stars such" as these are believed to be black
holes, and although by their very nature it is impossible
to get a picture of a black hole, a picture of a black hole
binary system may show us a black hole's effects on the
area around itself and its visible companion, thus verifying the existence of black holes.
Just as we have been inferring the existence of

black holes without an actual "picture" of one, so have
we inferred the existence of planets circling some nearby
stars. Stars which are suspected of having planetary
systems (such as Barnard's Star) exhibit a characteristically uneven wobble, but because of the optical limitations of ground-based telescopes, it has been impossible
to see any planets. A planet is a dim object compared to
its sun, so it is blotted out by the brightness of its star.
Because of the high resolution of the space telescope,
though, it should be able to see a Jupiter-sized or larger
planet if there is one there to see.
Modern cosmology, the study of the universe as a
whole, stands to be refined by the space telescope. In
the 1920's, Edwin Hubble discovered a clear correlation
between the distance of a galaxy from us and how fast it
is receding from us. (The major basis for the belief that
the universe is expanding is that all galaxies are moving
away from us.) There is a large range of error attached
to the Hubble constant (relation) which is caused by the
margin of error in our measurements of distance to
nearby galaxies. The space telescope will be able to pick
out important reference stars within neighborhood
galaxies and use them to get a more accurate measure
of distance to the galaxy. A by-product of the refinement of the Hubble constant will be better estimation of
the age of the universe, whose equation includes the
Hubble constant. The current estimate is 15 to 20
billion years, but a more exact Hubble constant will
place our finger closer to the exact figure.
These are merely the highlights of the research to
be done with the space telescope. Astronomers will be
training it on every interesting object in the heavens in a
mad dash to make the best use of their new toy. Without a doubt, the space telescope, which will be focus
of astrophysical research over the next two decades, is
one of the most important tools to fall into the hands of
pure science in recent times.

The importance of the NASA decision to locate
the Space Telescope Science Institute at Homewood is
difficult to judge. It will affect everything from office
space in Rowland Hall to man's view of the Universe.
Exactly what discoveries will be made is uncertain,
though certain ideas exist as to the kinds of things
man will be looking for.
The effect all this will have on Hopkins is also
difficult to ascertain, but some preliminary information
is circulating. Completion of the Institute is at least two
years away (in fact, construction won't start until this
summer). But Institute staff will begin their infiltration
this March. An initial staff of five is expected in early
March. They will be temporarily housed in Rowland
Hall until the Institute building is completed in 1983 or
1984. By May or June, 15 to 20 Institute staff members
will be cramming the halls of Rowland. After that, the
staff won't increase much until the Institute building is
completed.
The Space Telescope is already under construction. It will be placed in orbit about 375 miles above
the earth by the Space Shuttle in late 1984 or early
1985. The telescope will have a useful life of about 15
years. Adjunct Professor William Fastie of the Physics
department seemed to flinch slightly at the suggestion
that the Space Telescope, like Skylab, might drop out of
orbit and be destroyed. This is no longer a problem, he
asserts, because calculations of the earth's gravitational
pull are now more accurate. In addition, with the Space
Shuttle in operation, when and if the Space Telescope
were pulled too close to the earth, the shuttle could
simply go put it back where it belongs. (Fastie also
pointed out that if the government had adequately
funded the Space Shuttle project it would have probably
been operational in time to save the Skylab.) In addition to being able to adjust the Space Telescope's orbit,
the Space Shuttle will enable NASA to repair the telescope in space, as well as replace obsolete equipment
with more sophisticated equipment when and if desired.
The Institute will be constructed on the Homewood west campus, west of San Martin drive. The site is
north of the Athletic Center. Thouse definite plans have
not been made, the building will cover approximately
70,000 square feet, including parking. The present
design also had provisions for two 20,000-square-foot
extensions if the Institute needs to expand. The building will house a full time staff of about 140, 25 to 40 of
whom will be professional astronomers. In addition to
the full time staff, an estimated 200 astronomers are
expected to visit and use the facilities annually.
There will be no antennae at the Institute. All
communications between the Institute and the Space
Telescope will be handled through Goddard Space Flight
Center in Greenbelt, Md. The information from the
telescope will be relayed by one of two satellites to
Goddard, and then by cable from Goddard to the
Institute. Directional information for aiming the telescope will be formulated at the Institute and relayed
through Goddard and one of the two satellites to the
telescope.

a consortium of schools that run a number of observatories, the Kitt Peak Observatory, Cerra Tololo in Chile,

Quasars (short for quasi-stellar objects) were first discovered with radio telescopes and have remained an

Because quasars are extremely distant objects, our only
optical pictures of them are fuzzy at best. Several
conjectures have been made on what the quasars are, but
all of these guesses really depend upon getting a clearer
look at a quasar. Are quasars galaxies with enormous
black holes in their nuclei? Do they represent an early
stage in galactic evolution? (Since light travels at a
finite constant velocity and the quasars are uniformly

quasars? The fuzzy regions around the quasars are
